review.title: Temporal dynamics of semantic relations in word embeddings: an application to predicting armed conflict participants
review.abstract: This paper deals with using word embedding models to trace the temporal dynamics of semantic relations between pairs of words. The set-up is similar to the well-known analogies task, but expanded with a time dimension. To this end, we apply incremental updating of the models with new training texts, including incremental vocabulary expansion, coupled with learned transformation matrices that let us map between members of the relation. The proposed approach is evaluated on the task of predicting insurgent armed groups based on geographical locations. The gold standard data for the time span 1994--2010 is extracted from the UCDP Armed Conflicts dataset. The results show that the method is feasible and outperforms the baselines, but also that important work still remains to be done.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction and related work
sections.text: In this study, we attempt to model the dynamics of global armed conflicts on the basis of English news texts, using the well-known framework of continuous bag modeling (Mikolov et al., 2013c). We learn linear projections from the embedding of these groups. These projections are then applied to the embedding and gold standard data from the following year, whereby the entities turn out to be violent groups. To evaluate our approach, we adapt the violent armed groups to the embedding of these groups.

sections.heading: 1.1 Contributions
sections.text: The most important contributions of this paper are: 1. We show that distributional semantic models, especially word embedding, can be used not only to trace diachronic semantic shifts in words, but also the temporal dynamics of semantic relationships between word pairs. 2. The necessary prerequisites for achieving this task are a gradual updating of the models with new text data (rather than learning from scratch each time new data is added) and a way to expand the vocabulary of the models.

sections.heading: 2 Gold standard data on armed conflicts
sections.text: The UCDP / PRIO Armed Conflict Dataset maintained by the Uppsala Conflict Data Program and the Peace Research Institute Oslo is a manual annoted geographical and temporal dataset with information on a state, in the time from 1946 to the present (Gleditsch et al., 2002; Allansson et al., 2017). It encodes conflicts where at least one party is the government of a state. The Armed Conflict Dataset is widely used in statistical and macroeconomic conflict research; however, it has been adapted and introduced into the NLP field, starting with (Kutuzov et al., 2017).

sections.heading: 3 Predicting armed conflict participants
sections.text: In this section we will give a detailed description of our approach, starting with a synchronous example in 3.1 and continuing to a diachronic example for a few years in 3.2. In the next section 4 we will perform an evaluation of the complete test set.

sections.heading: 4 Evaluation of diachronic models
sections.text: In fact, most people are able to decide for themselves what they want.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: We have shown here how progressively updated word embedding models with vocabulary expansion and linear projection matrices are able to understand the dynamics of subtle semantic relationships over time. We applied this approach to the task of predicting armed groups active in specific geographical locations and showed that it clearly exceeds the basics, but it can be used for any kind of semantic relationship. We believe that studying time shifts of such projections can produce interesting results that go far beyond the usual example of "king is queen as well as man for woman." To the best of our knowledge, the behavior of semantic relationships in updated word embedding models has not yet been explored. Our experiments show that the models maintain these "directions" and that the predictions learned apply not only to the word pairs known to the original model, but can also be used to predict relationships for the new words.
